translated: Composed by Venerable Saá¹ƒghabhadra
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order

Chapter 3, Section 6: Distinguishing the Differences. Having already distinguished the definite correspondence between cause and effect, we will now correctly distinguish the differences in the characteristics of effects.
What are the characteristics of the effects such as retribution?
Verse:
Retribution is a neutral dharma. Sentient beings are born from karmic consciousness.
The outflowing effect resembles its own cause. The effect of disjunction is the exhaustion by wisdom.
If something is born by the power of that cause, this effect is called the effect of human effort.
Excluding the above conditioned dharmas, the conditioned dominant effect exists.
Discussion:
Only in the unobscured neutral dharmas is there the effect of retribution.
If that is so, then what is not included in sentient beings should also be retribution.
In order to distinguish that, it is said that sentient beings exist. Because only in sentient beings is there retribution.
If that is so, then among those included in sentient beings, the nourished and outflowing effects should be retribution.
Also, in order to distinguish it from the other two, it is said that the retribution of good and bad actions is born of the existent, because all bad and good impure dharmas can indicate retribution.
Retribution arises later, not simultaneously or immediately after, and therefore it is said that it is born of the existent.
This is the characteristic of retribution.

Isnâ€™t it true that retribution is also a similar cause for the substance of retribution in a prior state? Because it is a homogeneous cause, it is the cause of retribution. Then you should also say that it is born of the non-existent, because it is a homogeneous result. How is it that you say that it is born of the existent and is not a homogeneous result?

There is no such error. The substance of retribution is confused in its characteristics as a homogeneous cause, but the characteristics of the cause of retribution are not confused. Therefore it is said that it is born of the existent.
On the basis of this, we know that it is not a homogeneous result, because a homogeneous result is confused with its cause in characteristics.
If a result of retribution is not confused with its cause in characteristics, why is it not a result of retribution for insentient things?
Because they are equally enjoyed by all sentient beings who have equally created them.
The place of the great Brahma is created by the common karma of the great Brahmas. It is reasonable that other sentient beings can enjoy it.
How can the karma of many sentient beings create a single non-sentient result?
There is no error in this, because the homogeneous cause is one, while the karmic conditions are many.
Moreover, we see that a small amount of karma can produce many results. Why can't many results arise from many karmas?
There is no contradiction in the results of productive causes being few or many.
The power of the retributive cause is not like this, because the result is not shared.
Shared results are repeatedly created, but this is not the meaning of conforming to maturation. Therefore the results of retribution do not include non-sentient beings.
Results that resemble their causes are called results similar to their causes, which means that they resemble the two causes of the same category and omnipresent causes.
Like the cause of the same category, the nature of the results similar to their causes is also good, defiled, non-defined, etc.
Like the omnipresent cause, the nature of the results similar to their causes is also only defiled.
Donâ€™t the dominant results of simultaneous dharmas also resemble their causes?
How can you say that dharmas that resemble their causes are called results similar to their causes?

There are no results similar to their causes that do not resemble their causes, but there are dominant results that differ from their causes. Therefore, dharmas that resemble their causes are called results similar to their causes, and there is no error in the above definition.

Arenâ€™t there results similar to their causes that differ from their causes, such as the homogeneous cause, which produces a result that belongs to a different class? The similarity of defilement is called resemblance to its cause.
The nature of dominant results differs from its cause.
Moreover, a cause is that which possesses two similarities with its result.

The first is substance, that is, such things as feeling, and the second is nature, that is, such things as being good.ğŸ”½If the dominant result of a simultaneous dharma, its nature is the same as its cause, but its substance must differ, because two feelings, etc., do not occur simultaneously.
If the dominant result of a subsequent dharma, its nature and substance may differ, and therefore you cannot say that the result resembles its cause.
The nature of the effect similar to its cause must resemble the cause. It may also exist in the substance of the effect. Therefore, only this effect is said to resemble its cause.
However, these two causes are established separately because they are either broader or narrower. The effect is similar to its cause. Therefore, they are combined to form one.

The effect of disjunction is called the effect of disjunction because it is the extinction of wisdom. Extinction is called disjunction because it is the extinction of wisdom. Therefore, cessation through discrimination is called the effect of disjunction.
Because of the cause of discrimination, one is free from all bonds and realizes this cessation. Therefore, it is called the effect.
If a dharma is produced by the power of another, it is called the effect of the dominant condition.
There are four kinds of this, as has been explained above.
As for the simultaneously born, it means that dharmas produced by the power of being causes for each other at the same time.
As for the immediately antecedent, it means that which is born next, such as the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering born from the supreme worldly dharmas.
As for the separated, it means that which is born separated by time, such as the farmers and so on with regard to the grains and wheat and so on.
As for the phrase â€œthat which is not born,â€ this refers to nirvÄá¹‡a, because the power of the path of noninterruption causes it to be born.
Since it is not born, how can it be said to be the effect of the dominant result?
It is called the effect of the dominant result because it is born by the power of the path of noninterruption.
We see that birth is also spoken of with regard to obtaining, as in the statement, â€œMy wealth is born,â€ which means â€œI have obtained wealth.â€
The cessation resulting from discrimination that is realized by the path of noninterruption that eliminates the propensities is called the effect of separation and the effect of the dominant result.

If the cessation resulting from discrimination that is realized by the path of noninterruption is not the elimination of the propensities, it is only the effect of the dominant result, not the effect of separation.
The various states are discussed in the Abhidharmasamuccaya.
All conditioned dharmas, with the exception of those born previously, are the dominant results of other conditioned dharmas. There is no result that is born prior to its cause.
If the result were born prior to the cause, then the subsequent cause would be useless, and future dharmas would never be born.
What is the difference between the two results, the effect of the dominant result and the effect of the human action?

The name effect of the dominant result is given only to that which is created by the doer, while the name effect of the dominant result is given to that which is created by the doer and also to that which is created by others.
Among the six causes explained above, in what state do they take effects and give effects?
A verse says:
The five take effects only in the present, and two give effects in the same way.
Past and present give two causes, and one gives only in the past.
The treatise says:
The five causes take effects only in the present. They definitely are not in the past, because they have already taken them.
They are also not in the future, because they have no function.
As for taking effects, it means being able to attract, that is, attracting the future and causing it to arise, etc.

It can be a seed for the same kind, and for different kinds it is by the same effect. For that which is not a single effect, it is by the same nature. For different natures, it is because there is this continuity of one's own group. Therefore, all are called able to attract. This able to attract is called taking effects.
This function of taking effects only exists in the present, not in the past or future. Only this can be called the function of conditioned phenomena.
The three causes of corresponding, coexistent, and retribution are said to be called function by their power, because the effect is different from the cause and the two are simultaneous.
The term five excludes the efficient cause.
However, the efficient cause that can take an effect is definitely only in the present, and it takes the past and present.
It should be like the two causes of homogeneous and omnipresent, but not all.
There is an dominant effect that can be taken or given, so this is not discussed.
How does this cause only take an effect in the present?
As the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says:

Past dharmas become the equal and immediate condition to produce two minds, if the mind that exits from the attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation, because the mind that enters the two attainments takes it in the present, then the two attainments would never appear again, because the equal and immediate condition takes and gives together.
There is no such thing, the mind that enters the two attainments only in the present can take the effect of the two attainments and the mind that exits.

However, since the two samÄdhis are the correct objects of pursuit, one must first generate them. Because they are obstacles, the mind emerging from samÄdhi does not arise immediately after the mind entering samÄdhi.
In terms of the meaning of giving results, it is said that two minds arise in the past. This meaning will be further distinguished later.
Therefore the efficient cause, like the homogeneous cause and the universal cause, generally takes the future as its dominant result.
However, some say:
This efficient cause takes results and gives results, both in the past and present.
This is unreasonable, because the function of taking results exists only in the present.
The simultaneous and associated causes are also like this, only in the present. This is because these two causes take results and give results necessarily at the same time.
The two causes, homogeneous and universal, give results in the past and present.
Those with results among the efficient causes should be explained in the same way.
However, not all of them have results, so this is not discussed.

The two causes of similar and universal have as their outflow effect an effect that arises immediately, which is the present time. With regard to the effect that arises immediately, they also take it and also give it.
When this effect has already arisen and the two causes have already perished, they are said to have already taken it and already given it.
If these two causes perish and reach the past, and the outflow effect just reaches the time of arising, then these two causes first take the effect in the state of arising and now give it.
As for giving the effect, it means that these various causes are just giving it power to make it arise, etc. The efficient cause is just in the present.
That dominant effect has already arisen in the present, such as the eye faculty, etc., giving rise to the eye consciousness, etc.
There is arising immediately, such as the supreme worldly dharmas, etc., giving rise to the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma of suffering, etc.
There is arising with an interval, such as the wholesome roots conducive to liberation, etc., giving rise to the knowledge of extinction, etc., of the three vehicles' enlightenment.

There are four alternatives concerning homogeneous causes that are related or unrelated, that take or do not take results, and that are good, bad, etc. This should be understood in accordance with the extensive explanation in the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya.
The cause of retribution only gives results in the past, because the result of retribution is neither simultaneous with nor immediately antecedent to the cause.
Masters of the West say:
Apart from the five results, there are four other results: the result of added effort, the result of establishment, the result of combination, and the result of cultivation.
These are all included in the result of human effort and the dominant result. Therefore it is said that there are only five results.
Having discussed causes and results, we should consider how many causes produce which dharmas.
In this regard, dharmas are generally of four kinds: defiled dharmas, dharmas born of retribution, the first pure dharma, and the remaining dharmas.
What are the remaining dharmas?
They are indeterminate dharmas other than those born of retribution.
They are good dharmas other than the first pure dharma.
These four dharmas are as follows:ğŸ”½Defiled, karmically-matured, the rest, and the first holy, are respectively
Excluding karmically-matured, omnipresent, and the second, and the same type, the rest arise.
This refers to mind and mental factors, the rest, and excluding the associated.
The treatise says:
All defiled dharmas, excluding the karmically-matured cause, arise from the remaining five causes, because the dharmas produced by the karmically-matured cause are not defiled.
Karmically-matured dharmas, excluding the omnipresent cause, arise from the remaining five causes, because the dharmas produced by the omnipresent cause are only defiled.

The remaining dharmas, excluding both the karmically-matured and omnipresent causes, arise from the remaining four causes, because the remaining dharmas are not karmically-matured and are not defiled.

The first pure dharma, excluding the same type, and the word and indicates that the karmically-matured and omnipresent causes are also excluded, and arise from the remaining three causes, because the first pure dharma has no previously arisen same type dharma, and because it is wholesome.
What are the four dharmas?
You should know that they are only mind and mental activities.
If this is so, how many causes are the remaining dharmas, i.e., the dissociated forces and the four dharmas, born from?

You should know that, excluding causes and excluding the associated cause, the remaining dharmas are born from four, three, two, and the remaining causes.ğŸ”½That is, defiled form and dissociated forces, like mind and mental activities, are born from four causes, excluding the cause of retribution and excluding the associated cause.
Form and dissociated forces born of retribution, like mind and mental activities, are born from four causes, excluding the cause of universal retá¹›ibution and excluding the associated cause.

The remaining form and dissociated forces, like mind and mental activities, are born from three causes, excluding the two causes of retribution and universal retribution and excluding the associated cause.
The first pure form and dissociated forces, like mind and mental activities, are born from two causes, excluding the preceding three causes and excluding the associated cause.
There is no dharma born from one cause.
Now we should consider which dharmas can be of how many kinds of causes by their own-natures.
That is to say, there are some dharmas that are fully able to be of six kinds of causes by their own-natures, and so on, down to dharmas that are able to be of one kind of cause by their own-natures.
Among these, dharmas that are fully able to be of six kinds of causes by their own-natures are all past and present unwholesome and universal mind and mental factors.

Dharmas that are able to be of five kinds of causes by their own-natures are all past and present unwholesome and non-universal mind and mental factors, or indeterminate universal mind and mental factors, or wholesome contaminated mind and mental factors, or unwholesome universal non-associated compositional factors.

There are dharmas that can be the nature of four causes, namely the past and present unwholesome form dharmas, or wholesome contaminated form dharmas, or form dharmas not associated with mind, or unwholesome non-pervasive dharmas not associated with mind, or indeterminate pervasive dharmas not associated with mind, or indeterminate non-pervasive mind and mental factors, or all uncontaminated mind and mental factors, or all future unwholesome and wholesome contaminated mind and mental factors.ğŸ”½There are dharmas that can be the nature of three causes, namely the past and present indeterminate form dharmas, or indeterminate non-pervasive dharmas not associated with mind, or uncontaminated form dharmas not associated with mind, or future unwholesome and wholesome contaminated form dharmas not associated with mind, or indeterminate uncontaminated mind and mental factors.
There are dharmas that can be the nature of two causes, namely all future indeterminate uncontaminated form dharmas not associated with mind.

There is a dharma that can be a single cause, namely unconditioned dharmas. There is no dharma that is not a cause, nor is there a dharma that is not a result, namely space and non-analytical cessation.

We should further consider that the six causes, in terms of their intrinsic natures, may be pure or mixed. First, regarding the efficient cause in relation to the co-existent cause, the latter is subsequent to the former, meaning that the co-existent cause must be mixed with the efficient cause.
There is pure efficient cause that is not a co-existent cause, namely unconditioned dharmas.
Moreover, the efficient cause in relation to the homogeneous cause is also subsequent to the latter, meaning that the homogeneous cause must be mixed with the efficient cause.
There is pure efficient cause that is not a homogeneous cause, namely future dharmas and unconditioned dharmas.
Moreover, the efficient cause in relation to the associated cause is also subsequent to the latter, meaning that the associated cause must be mixed with the efficient cause.
There is pure efficient cause that is not an associated cause, namely form dharmas, dissociated compositional factors, and unconditioned dharmas.
Moreover, the efficient cause in relation to the pervasive cause is also subsequent to the latter, meaning that the pervasive cause must be mixed with the efficient cause.
There is pure activity as cause that is not a universal cause, namely, future dharmas, past and present dharmas that are not universal, and unconditioned dharmas.

translated: Activity as cause and retributive cause are also in the latter category, i.e., there is pure activity as cause that is not retributive cause, namely, nondetermined dharmas and pure dharmas.

translated: Concomitant cause and similar cause are also in the latter category, i.e., there is pure concomitant cause that is not similar cause, namely, future dharmas.

translated: Concomitant cause and associated cause are also in the latter category, i.e., there is pure concomitant cause that is not associated cause, namely, dharmas of form and dharmas not directly associated with thought.

Concomitant cause and universal cause are also in the latter category, i.e., there is pure concomitant cause that is not universal cause, namely, future dharmas, past and present dharmas that are not universal.
Also, co-existent causes in relation to causes of retribution are also in accordance with the latter phrase, that is, causes of retribution are necessarily mixed with co-existent causes.
There are pure co-existent causes that are not causes of retribution, namely, the indeterminate and pure dharmas among the conditioned dharmas.
If homogeneous causes in relation to associated causes are considered, four sentences should be made.
The first sentence is past and present form and dharmas not directly associated with mind.
The second sentence is future mind and mental activities.
The third sentence is past and present mind and mental activities.
The fourth sentence is future form, dharmas not directly associated with mind, and unconditioned dharmas.
Also, homogeneous causes in relation to universal causes are in accordance with the latter phrase, that is, universal causes are necessarily mixed with homogeneous causes.
There are pure homogeneous causes that are not universal causes, namely, past and present dharmas that are not universal.
Also, homogeneous causes in relation to causes of retribution should be made into four sentences.
The first sentence is past and present indeterminate and pure dharmas.
The second phrase refers to future unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas.
The third phrase refers to past and present unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas.
The fourth phrase refers to future indeterminate and uncontaminated dharmas, as well as unconditioned dharmas.
If the associated cause is compared to the universal cause, four sentences should be made.
The first sentence refers to future mind and mental factors, and past and present non-universal mind and mental factors.
The second sentence refers to past and present universal non-associated compositional factors.
The third sentence refers to past and present universal mind and mental factors.
The fourth sentence refers to all material form dharmas, future non-associated compositional factors, past and present non-universal non-associated compositional factors, and unconditioned dharmas.
Moreover, if the associated cause is compared to the ripening cause, four sentences are also made.
The first sentence refers to indeterminate and uncontaminated mind and mental factors.
The second phrase refers to unwholesome and wholesome contaminated form and dissociated formations.
The third phrase refers to unwholesome and wholesome contaminated mental factors and mental activities.
The fourth phrase refers to indeterminate and uncontaminated form and dissociated formations, as well as unconditioned dharmas.
If the universal cause is compared with the retributive cause, four sentences should be made.
The first sentence refers to past and present indeterminate universal dharmas.
The second sentence refers to future unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas, and past and present wholesome contaminated and unwholesome non-universal dharmas.
The third sentence refers to past and present unwholesome universal dharmas.
The fourth sentence refers to future indeterminate and uncontaminated dharmas, and past and present uncontaminated and indeterminate non-universal dharmas, as well as unconditioned dharmas.

You should also consider the distinctions among the six causes in terms of form and non-form, etc. This means that among the six causes, the associated cause and the universal cause are not form, while the remaining four causes are both form and non-form.
It should be understood that the same is true for the visible and the invisible, and for the resistant and the non-resistant.
Moreover, among the six causes, only the associated cause is a concomitant dharma, while the remaining causes are both concomitant and non-concomitant dharmas.

It should be understood that the same is true for the supported and the unsupported, the aroused and the non-aroused, the having aspects and the having no aspects, and the having objects and the having no objects.
Moreover, among the six causes, only the universal cause and the karmic maturation cause are contaminated, while the remaining four causes are both contaminated and uncontaminated.
Moreover, among the six causes, the efficient cause is both conditioned and unconditioned, while the remaining five causes are only conditioned.
Moreover, among the six causes, only the universal cause is defiled, while the remaining five causes are both defiled and undefiled.

It should be understood that the same is true of whether there is an offense or not, whether it is black or white, whether it is covered or not covered, and whether it is conducive to regression or not conducive to regression.
Moreover, among the six causes, the one cause of karmic retribution only has karmic retribution, while the remaining five causes both have karmic retribution and do not have karmic retribution.

Moreover, among the six causes, the one cause of being able to act both extends through the three times and does not extend through time. The three causes of co-existence, association, and karmic retribution all extend through the three times. The two causes of similar species and universal permeation only extend through the past and present.

translated: Moreover, among the six causes, the one cause of universal permeation is unwholesome and indeterminate, while the one cause of karmic retribution extends through wholesome and unwholesome. The remaining four causes all extend through the three natures.ğŸ”½Moreover, among the six causes, the two causes of universal permeation and karmic retribution both extend through the three realms of existence, while the remaining four causes both extend through the three realms of existence and do not extend through existence.

Moreover, among the six causes, the two causes of universal permeation and karmic retribution are both neither learners nor post-learners, while the remaining four causes all extend through the three kinds [of learners, post-learners, and neither learners nor post-learners].

Also, among the six causes, the one cause of universal permeation is only eliminated by insight, the one cause of karmic retribution is either eliminated by insight or eliminated by cultivation, and the remaining four causes are either eliminated by insight or cultivation or are not eliminated.

Also, among the six causes, the one cause of enabling is subsumed under the four truths and is not subsumed under the truths, the two causes of universal permeation and karmic retribution are only subsumed under the truth of suffering and the truth of accumulation, and the remaining three causes are subsumed under the three truths of suffering, accumulation, and the path.

Also, among the six causes, the associated and universal permeation causes are only subsumed under the four aggregates, the three causes of co-existent, similar, and karmic retribution are subsumed under the five aggregates, and the one cause of enabling is subsumed under the five aggregates and is not subsumed under the aggregates.

Also, among the six causes, the associated and universal permeation causes are subsumed under the mental faculty and dharmas, the one cause of karmic retribution is subsumed under the four bases of form, sound, mental faculty, and dharmas, and the remaining three causes are subsumed under the twelve bases.

Also, among the six causes, the omnipresent cause is included in the three realms of mind, dharmas, and mental consciousness. The associated cause is included in the seven mental realms and the dharma realm. The karmic retribution cause is included in the form, sound, and seven mental realms and the dharma realm. The remaining three causes are included in the eighteen realms.
These various distinctions in causes and effects cannot be fully understood without omniscience.
I have briefly explained their characteristics according to my understanding of the meaning of causes and effects. To further clarify and discern the conditions,
what are the conditions?
The verse states:
It is said there are four kinds of conditions, with the causal condition having the nature of five causes,
The immediately preceding condition is not after, but the already arisen mind and mental factors,
The objective condition is all dharmas, and the dominant condition is the enabling cause.
The treatise states:
Where is this taught?
It is taught in the sutras.
The four conditions are the nature of causal condition, the nature of homogeneous immediate condition, the nature of object condition, and the nature of dominant condition.

Here, the nature of condition is precisely the four conditions, just as the nature of what is to be inhabited is precisely the four kinds of what is to be inhabited. The word nature is used to indicate the species. The meaning is that the various conditions, according to their differences in function, have innumerable natures.
However, when their meanings are summarized, they are all included in the four species. That is to say, all conditions are not beyond these natures.
Among the six causes, excluding the efficient cause, the remaining five causes are the nature of causal condition.
As the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says:
What is causal condition?
It refers to all conditioned dharmas.
Since the treatise does not say that it also includes unconditioned dharmas, the five causes are established as the nature of causal condition.
Why is unconditioned [dharma] not established as causal condition?
This is explained as above. Only the unobstructed abiding is established as the efficient cause, not included in the other causes.
Although the nature of dharmas is originally existent and not nonexistent, their functioning and accomplishment must depend on the power of causes.
Just as the substance of derivative form is originally not nonexistent, but its function and accomplishment must depend on the primary elements.
Among causes, the most excellent are the five causes, as there are no five most excellent causes for derivative form.
The already-arisen mind and mental factors, with the exception of the final mind and mental factors of arhats, are all generally referred to as the similar and immediately antecedent condition.
The phrase already arisen is used to exclude future dharmas and unconditioned dharmas.
The phrase mind and mental factors is used to exclude form and the factors not associated with mind.
Why is the similar and immediately antecedent condition only mind and mental factors?
Because it accords with the meaning of the similar and immediately antecedent condition.
This condition refers to dharmas that are similar and immediately antecedent. The name similar and immediately antecedent is established based on this meaning.
In a single continuity, two dharmas of the same type do not arise simultaneously, and for this reason it is called similar.
Because there is no similar dharma to obstruct it in the interval, it is called uninterrupted.

If it is said that this result is called uninterrupted because it arises without interruption, then the mind and so on of one emerging from the attainment of non-perception should not be called uninterrupted.
Or, it is called uninterrupted because no similar dharma arises in the interval. This means that no similar dharma is allowed to arise in the interval between the two.
Or, the class of mind and mental factors that arise together with the preceding [moment] is a condition for the subsequent class without interruption.
It is not only similar types that are called uninterrupted.
Why is this?
Because in one body, mind and mental factors do not have two substances arising together as similar types, because there is no second condition as an equal and immediate antecedent.
Why is there no second condition as an equal and immediate antecedent?
Because the mind of each sentient being evolves as one.
Why does each [sentient being] have only one mind evolving?
Because when the mind is scattered and engaged with other objects, it does not cognize other objects.
Moreover, when the mind is concentrated on one object, the distracted mind that is concerned with other objects definitely does not arise.
Moreover, if there are many minds in a single stream of consciousness, there would be no one who could control the mind.
Moreover, if many minds arise simultaneously in a single body, are their objects different or are they associated?
If they are associated, then one object and one characteristic are without distinction, and their simultaneous arising is useless.
If their objects are different, then defiled and pure, good and bad, would arise together, and there would be no liberation.
There is also a definitive teaching that proves that a single sentient being has only one mind continuum that evolves.
That is, a scripture says:
When one experiences a pleasant feeling, at that time the other two feelings are both extinguished.
Also, a scripture says:
The mind is solitary and travels alone.
How do we definitely know that when mind and mental activities arise, they must rely on a condition as similar and immediately antecedent?
Because a scripture says:
And the attention that produces them is present. It is definitely known that they arise because of the wisdom of awareness that precedes them.
If it were not so, what principle could prevent the sudden appearance of sentient beings where there were none before?
Why is it said that the final mind and mental activities of arhats are not similar and immediately antecedent conditions?
Because they do not attract subsequent fruits.
Why are they devoid of the ability to attract fruits?
Because at that time they are supported by other conditions.
We reply, if you admit that they are supported by other conditions, why not admit that the subsequent consciousness is born because of the power of these other conditions? What harm is there in that?
If they can attract subsequent , then, like the mind and mental activities of the prior stage, they can also give rise to fruits.

If, because of being supported by other conditions, they are devoid of the meaning of giving rise to fruits, then they must be devoid of the ability to attract fruits because of being supported by other conditions.

Or, mind and mental activities in the act of perishing are able to attract and give rise to the similar and immediately antecedent conditions of the dharmas in the act of origination, and this is called similar and immediately antecedent condition.

The final mind, etc., of arhats, in the act of perishing, have no dharmas in the act of origination that are similar and immediately antecedent, and for that reason it cannot be said that they are similar and immediately antecedent conditions.

If this is so, then the mind and mental activities of the two mindless samÄdhis and the mind and mental activities of the present moment of arising and cessation should not be said to be the condition as cause, because they do not exist.
They are called similar and immediately antecedent because they will definitely arise.
The nonassociated cannot arise immediately, but since they will definitely arise, there is no error in saying that they arise.
The homogeneous cause, etc., do not have a fixed time for taking an effect, and for that reason they cannot be used as an analogy.
Why is it not admitted that the future mind and mental activities are similar and immediately antecedent conditions?
Similar and immediately antecedent conditions are established on the basis of a definite sequence in the past and present, but the future has no definite sequence.
If it already has a definite sequence, then the practice of the path would be useless.

Even though the cause and effect of retribution have a definite sequence, they are established on the basis of their characteristics and not on the basis of sequence, and for that reason they are said to exist in the future. This cannot be used as an analogy.
If there is no definite sequence in the future, how can the World Honored One predict the time of death?
The virtues and functions of buddhas are inconceivable. Past, future, and present causes and effects can all be directly perceived.
Some say:
In the bodies of present sentient beings, there are already signs of future causes and effects. The Buddha observes these and thus knows the future.

Directly seeing and verifying is clear, not the knowledge of divination. The Buddha has a reason for being able to directly see and verify in the dense forest of such things, but it is not that he can do so without a reason as an all-knowing one.
Since it can function with regard to objects such as form, why is the condition as an equivalent and immediate antecedent not established for form and the dissociated factors?
Because in one body, the same type arises simultaneously, either many or few, not as an equivalent and immediate antecedent.
If that is so, the life faculty does not arise simultaneously with two. Why is it not allowed to rely on the condition as an equivalent and immediate antecedent?
It arises through the power of past karma, not led by previous life.
Although mind and mental factors arise from past karma, they rely on objects and faculties, which cannot be taken as an example.
Also, it is not definitely born as a maturation.
However, the VibhÄá¹£Ä says:
Mind and its activities are restricted in regard to support, object, aspect, and mode of activity. For this reason, they are established as similar and immediately antecedent conditions.
Form and thoughtconcomitants are not like this.

This condition is not established merely on the basis of making room for the arising of subsequent dharmas, but also on the basis of the power to attract and generate. Therefore, although atoms, etc., make room for subsequent dharmas, they are not similar and immediately antecedent conditions.

The generation of mind and its activities is sometimes definite and sometimes indefinite. Therefore we know that the power to attract and generate is also based on this condition. The definite and indefinite are as discussed in the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya.
Mind and its activities are born from their own causes. What is the function of the immediately antecedent condition that has already perished?

Even though the organs and objects are combined in the present, there is no simultaneous arising of consciousness and its activities of the same species. Therefore we know that when the immediately antecedent condition has perished, it has the power to attract and generate subsequent mind and its activities.
Form and thoughtconcomitants are not like this. As it is said:
What are the dharmas that are similar and immediately antecedent?
That is, other minds and mental activities are born or are being born immediately after mind, and also the attainment of non-discrimination, and so on.
The words â€œalready bornâ€ include the past and present, and the words â€œbeing bornâ€ include the future moment of birth.

If this is so, then the mind of entry into samÄdhi in the second moment and subsequent minds in samÄdhi and minds leaving samÄdhi are not similar and immediately antecedent conditions for mind, because the mind of entry has not yet been born. When it is born later, it is called similar and immediately antecedent.
Because it is not interrupted by other similar and immediately antecedent conditions, the later is also called similar and immediately antecedent in relation to the former.
Also, that which will definitely arise is called the moment of birth, because the result will definitely arise once it is grasped.
If this is so, then it contradicts the text of the Abhidharmasamuccaya.
It asks:
If a dharma is a similar and immediately antecedent condition for a certain dharma, is it possible that this dharma is not a similar and immediately antecedent condition for that dharma at some time?
It then answers:
When this dharma has not yet reached the state of being born.
What contradiction is there?
Similar and immediately antecedent conditions definitely reach the state of being born.
However, there are two interpretations of this, both without contradiction.
When this dharma has not yet arisen,
what is this dharma?
Is it prior or posterior?

For example, when the supreme worldly dharmas give rise to the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering, are the supreme worldly dharmas not the similar and immediately antecedent condition for the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering when they have not yet arisen and reached the state of having arisen? Or are they the similar and immediately antecedent condition when they have arisen?

Or is the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering not the similar and immediately antecedent condition for the supreme worldly dharmas when it has not yet arisen and reached the state of having arisen? Or is it the similar and immediately antecedent condition when it has arisen?
If one holds the former, it is possible in the state of having mind, but how is it in the state of no mind?

That is to say, when the mind of entry into the concentration of no mind has already arisen, it cannot immediately be the similar and immediately antecedent condition for the second moment of concentration and the mind of exit.

If the mind of entry into samÄdhi, when it has already arisen, is the similar and immediately antecedent condition of those dharmas, then the dharma that is the effect of the similar and immediately antecedent condition, when it is about to arise, there is no dharma that can obstruct its arising, then all of them should arise simultaneously.
If the mind of emergence arises immediately after the mind of entry, then the two samÄdhis should never arise.

If you maintain the latter, then when the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering has not yet arisen, it should not be the similar and immediately antecedent condition of the supreme worldly dharmas.

However, you must certainly admit that when the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering is in the process of arising, it is called the similar and immediately antecedent condition of those supreme worldly dharmas.

In this regard, one group approves of the former assertion, but the text of the Abhidharmasamuccaya speaks of the similar and immediately antecedent condition in terms of the state of having mind, so there is no error in the former.
Or it is said that even if it is discussed in terms of the state without mind, this error does not exist.

That is to say, the mind of entry into samÄdhi, when it is in the present state, suddenly takes all samÄdhis and the effect of the mind of emergence, and also gives rise to the effect of the first moment of samÄdhi, which has already ceased and entered the past.
The samÄdhi that follows and the mind that emerges from samÄdhi are born one after another, and when they are born they do not grasp a result, because they have already grasped it.
Isnâ€™t it true that all similar and immediately antecedent conditions grasp and give up their results at the same time?
This criticism is unreasonable, because the result is grasped all at once, but given up gradually, and therefore there is no error.
We should criticize you and say, â€œThe result of a single mind is the same. Why are samÄdhi and the mind that emerges from samÄdhi born in sequence and not simultaneously?â€
The reason is that that which is sought must necessarily be born first. That is, the mind that enters samÄdhi seeks samÄdhi, and therefore samÄdhi must be born first immediately after the mind.
If this is so, why are the various moments of samÄdhi born in sequence?
The various moments of samÄdhi are born together and have no function, and therefore they are not born together.

They are attracted by the power of prior practice, and therefore many moments of samÄdhi continue to be born for a long time. They are not born together, because many moments of samÄdhi have no function of arising together, and because what one moment of samÄdhi cannot do, many moments cannot do. They are not born suddenly, just as consciousness and other dharmas are not.
However, all samÄdhis and concentrations are similar and immediately antecedent conditions, but they cannot be said to be similar and immediately antecedent conditions.

If a dharma is aroused by a previous mind, etc., is of the same species, and necessarily does not arise simultaneously, and having arisen, again arouses a subsequent dharma, it can be called similar and immediately antecedent and a similar and immediately antecedent condition.

Although samÄdhi is aroused by a previous mind, etc., is of the same species, and necessarily does not arise simultaneously, nevertheless, having arisen, it is unable to arouse a subsequent dharma. It can be called similar and immediately antecedent but not a similar and immediately antecedent condition.
Therefore, even if we discuss the state of no mind, there is no error.
There are those who say:

The mind that enters the two samÄdhis ceases and enters the past, and only then can it gradually take the second moment of samÄdhi and the mind that emerges from samÄdhi. The mind that enters samÄdhi should not be past.

The one who takes a result is the one who attracts a result. All the ones who attract a result are the activity of dharmas. The distinctions of the three time periods are established based on the activity of dharmas.
If there is activity but it is not present, how can it avoid destroying the basis of the distinction of time periods?
Some masters say:
The past eye, etc., do not have the various specific functions of seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, and touching with regard to form, etc., and therefore are not present.
This explanation is not correct. We should carefully examine the function of the eye, etc. Is it the power of seeing, etc., with regard to the object? Or is it the function of attracting a result?
If it is the power of seeing, etc., with regard to the object, then the present eye, etc., in the dark
are no different from the eye, etc., that have not yet arisen or have already perished, and you should not say that they are future or past.
Even though the eye, etc., in the dark do not have the function of seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, etc., they all have the power of attracting results in the present and can be called function.
All that has this function is called present.
The remaining functions of apprehending objects, giving results, etc., are not functions but powers.
Such powers may exist in the three time periods. We will consider this in detail in the discussion of the three time periods.
Also, past minds and mental activities cannot obstruct the objects of their activity, etc., and therefore they cannot be conditions as objects in the taking of a subsequent effect.

There is another interpretation that agrees with the latter opinion. Why not say that when the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering is in the process of arising, it is the similar and immediately antecedent condition of the supreme factors?
This is really so, but here it is said that the similar and immediately antecedent condition must be established as a condition after it has already arisen. Therefore there is no error.
These two interpretations of the phrase not yet arisen do not contradict our interpretation.

The condition as object consists of all dharmas, because apart from the objects of mind and mental activities, no other dharmas can be found. All dharmas are that which is born and that which is grasped by mind and mental activities, and for that reason they are called objects.
These objects are the condition for the generation of mind and mental activities and are therefore called the condition as object.

All dharmas are the twelve sense bases, namely, eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness, and the associated dharmas, which take various forms, sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, and dharmas as their objects, in that order.
The six sense bases are only the objects of mental consciousness.
Why is this known?
A sÅ«tra says:
Because many dharmas give rise to mental consciousness.
Also, the sense bases such as the eye are not included in the objects of the five consciousnesses, because what is cognized and known pervades all dharmas.

The objects of the five consciousnesses are only real, not provisional, while those of mental consciousness are both real and provisional. The objects of all minds and mental activities exist, not non-existing.

Refuting other schools is like the Correct Principles.ğŸ”½However, the objects of mind and mental activities are definitely determined, namely, eye consciousness, etc., with regard to the forms they perceive, up to mental consciousness, etc., with regard to the various dharmas they perceive.
Are the objects of these minds and mental activities determined in terms of realm, type, or moment?

Some say that the object is the objective realm, that is, eye consciousness only has form as its object, and the others each have their own objects as appropriate. Do not say that many minds and mental activities do not arise with regard to a single object, and therefore the others are not definitely so.
Moreover, eye consciousness, etc., with regard to all forms, arise with any form as object.
If this is so, how is the substance of the consciousnesses of blue, yellow, etc., not confused?
To avoid this confusion, it is said that the object is the objective realm, not a moment.

If this is so, how is the substance of the consciousnesses of blue, yellow, etc., not confused? It should be said that the object, the objective realm, and the moment are all definitely so. Do not say that many minds and mental activities do not arise with regard to a single object.
This is not a mistake, because the future is wide and can accommodate.
Moreover, minds and mental activities, with regard to their own objects, first perceive and know and later are able to remember.

Moreover, the objects of the five consciousnesses, etc., are remembered by the mental consciousness, etc., but the five consciousnesses, etc., cannot remember them, because the previous moment of consciousness takes only one instant as its object and is devoid of discrimination.
The manas is of two kinds, defiled and undefiled, and the first kind of consciousness that is able to remember is that of the same kind, i.e., defiled manas.
It is of three kinds, good, defiled, and indeterminate, and the first kind of consciousness that is able to remember is that of the same kind, i.e., good manas.

It is of four kinds, good, bad, obscured indeterminate, and non-obscured indeterminate, and the first kind of consciousness that is able to remember is that of the same kind, i.e., good consciousness.

It is of five kinds, i.e., eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of suffering, origination, and cessation, and by the path of cultivation, and the first kind of consciousness that is able to remember is that of the same kind, i.e., that eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of suffering.
Consciousness eliminated by the paths of insight into the truths of the path and cessation is able to remember four kinds, each lacking one of the above kinds.
Extending this line of reasoning, there are twelve kinds, i.e., four in the realm of desire, three in each of the two upper realms, and learners and post-learners.
Good consciousness in the realm of desire is able to remember twelve kinds,
The same applies to good cognition of unwholesome form.
Eight can recall unwholesome and unwholesome-neutral cognitions, excluding form-realm wholesome and formless-realm three types.
Ten can recall form-realm wholesome cognitions, excluding desire-realm wholesome and unwholesome-neutral.
The same applies to formless-realm wholesome cognitions.
Ten can recall form-realm unwholesome-neutral cognitions, excluding formless-realm wholesome and unwholesome-neutral.
Nine can recall formless-realm wholesome and unwholesome-neutral cognitions, excluding desire-realm wholesome and unwholesome-neutral.
Eleven can recall learner cognitions, excluding desire-realm wholesome and unwholesome-neutral and non-learner cognitions.
The cognition of the type liable to retrogress is the same as that of learners.
If of the type not liable to retrogress, seven can recall, excluding learner and the four of the three realms.
The various categories of the twenty types of defiled cognition and so on, as well as the cognition and recall of each, should be considered in accordance with reason.
The dominant condition is the efficient cause, because the meaning of cause is subtle and without limit, and includes all dharmas.
If this does not obstruct the arising of that, it is the efficient cause.
The meaning of dominant condition is the most numerous of the three conditions, and its function is very extensive, and therefore it is called dominant.
Isn't the dominant condition all-encompassing? How can it be opposed to the other three?
This dominant condition is not established as the dominant condition in opposition to the three natures.
What is established in opposition to the meaning and function of the three?
The meaning and function of the conditions do not mutually penetrate, and the natures of the conditions are further mutually mixed.
Just as the meaning of the dominant condition is immeasurable and its function is extensive, the other three are not like this, and therefore this alone is called the dominant condition.
In order to include the meanings not included by the five causes and three conditions, the efficient cause and dominant condition are established.

Because these two kinds of objects are the most extensive in terms of meaning and type, they are established as general terms, just like the term aggregate of karmic forces, the element of dharmas, the sense base of dharmas, the jewel of dharmas, the refuge of dharmas, the application of mindfulness to dharmas, and so on.
Other masters say:
This dominant condition has the most numerous types of substance, and therefore it is called dominant.
Although the nature of the condition as object is universal to all dharmas, it does not extend to the simultaneous, and therefore the name dominant is eliminated because of the narrow scope.
Other masters further say:
It is called the dominant condition because the objects it produces are extensive.
That is, all dharmas, with the exception of itself, are able to universally produce all conditioned dharmas.
When a single moment of eye consciousness is produced, with the exception of its own nature, all dharmas are used as dominant conditions.
The other productions are also like this.
The extent of this condition's substance and function is boundless.

As a scripture says: â€œThe three superior faculties of the world are the superior faculties of stopping evil, practicing good, and observing causes.â€ The name â€œsuperior facultyâ€ is established because they are the causes that are observed. That is, when afflictions are about to arise in the present realm, one observes any one of them, stops evil, and practices good. Among stopping and practicing, one obtains superiority, and therefore they are called superior faculties.
A scripture only says that there are three superior faculties, not others, because there is no meaning of superiority in the others.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
NyÄyÄnusÄra Å›Ästra, fascicle 10
